Well, I have to say that after Bioshock Remastered and Bioshock 2 Remastered I was kind of looking forward to Infinite. 
I was hoping that I wouldn't necessarily have to play my way through different levels as Big Daddy equipped with drills and ... surprise !

[b]Bioshock Infinite exceeded all of my expectations.[/b] 
The advantage is that if you haven't played part one and two, you don't have to worry that you have missed something of the story, because Infinite has absolutely nothing to do with the other two parts and you can fully concentrate on the (new) adventure.

As Booker DeWitt, Bioshock Infinite takes you to Columbia, a city in the clouds.
The graphics and the level design are, however, that the game is now around 8 years old, really impressive, well made and pretty to look at.
Your job as Booker DeWitt is actually very simple and easy. Bring the young woman Elizabeth from Columbia to New York. Well, what can I say. It won't be that easy after all.

[b]At this point I would dare to say that the game, for a shooter, has an extraordinary and good story.[/b]

Columbia, the cloud city, is not as expected or suspected, the underwater rapture that floats. Columbia is not a city to explore like Rapture and serves more as a backdrop, but a really impressive and breathtaking atmosphere with a lot of life and a gripping history.
The game's shooter elements are just as good and just plain fun from start to finish. It is by no means easy and I would also clearly say that if you play the game at the hardest level, then it is even more fun. I immediately dedicated myself to the unlockable 1999 mode because I just wanted to know.

This level of difficulty makes the game more of a "stealth game" in the Wolfenstein sense, but I think this has immense advantages.
For one, it's a completely different experience and you don't just have to be careful not to die. As a result, you don't simply "run" through the different levels, because the game absolutely doesn't deserve that, but you automatically have enough time to collect all the collectibles and to complete the (unfortunately) few optional side missions. 

Carrying "only" two weapons at the same time and the continuing shortage of ammunition does not make it any easier. For this you have up to eight forces (vigors) that support you in the fight and prove to be more than just practical.

[b]I enjoyed the game a lot, but there will be some who don't share my opinion, because the game leaves some questions unanswered and much to be desired. In the sense of "Lost" it is either a "WTF just happened here" or a "WOW"[/b]

I've always loved the Bioshock series but when Infinite came out, it was a feat in my opinion.  To have a bright and vibrant game that still gave you the sense of dread here and there with a great story telling aspect to it.  It's the total package.  There are very few games that have trapped me in a story such as this, I'm saddened Ken Levine won't be a part of the new one, but I'm still excited to see what will come of the series moving forward.

Still as good as the first time I played it. Beautiful world full of sinister characters. Gripping plot. Noone is quite what they seem. The Skyhook in this game is a fun way to travel and works well to surprise enemies from above in combat. Some fun powers and gear. The Handyman is like the Big Daddy of the game, quite difficult to beat. The rift powers where you can beam in a turret from another dimension really help with battles. Really annoying when you run out of ammo but there's always a vending machine nearby. It's one of those games you can complete, forget about for a while and then replay and it seems brand new.

For those with challenged hardware, the Bioshock series offer a great rail-shooter experience that won't overclock limited resources. I run a 2015 i7 with 8GBs of ram and an integrated video card. The game files are stored on an external USB 3.0 Flash drive. Solid fun with limited lag - the developers did a solid job balancing the water and visual effects against gameplay and 8 years on, Bioshock:Infinite gives good story and puzzles that will keep many entertained.

Good Game

Gameplay: I liked it, but it is a great departure from the original Bioshock gameplay. One way to go, no stealth, speed around and shoot everything to win. The 2 weapon system is also kind of nonsense, I think I would have been far more comfortable with 3. Annoying, but you can live with it.

Story: I like it, and I think it makes sense, but some don't. For those who think it makes sense and isn't pure nonsense, you'll probably enjoy the ending twist. It's an insane enough revelation you'll likely be dumbstruck for a while. Think about it while credits are rolling, cause there's a post credit scene you shouldn't miss.

Atmosphere: Very different from Bioshock. I liked it more than Rapture, because Rapture was a dead city, its best day behind it. Columbia is alive, and that makes it far more interesting to me. It doesn't have that same spooky atmosphere Bioshock did though. Also, the propaganda videos and vending machine voicelines were copied over, but they're far less natural and look worse. Well I supposed Columbia was on 1920 tech and Bioshock was on 1960 tech so that's the reason.

Visuals: One issue: The female nps in the beginning share the same unnatural looking model. It might have been fine if it was the same for the male models, but there are multiple male models that all look natural, so the female models looking weird looks worse by comparison. Luckily the female models get better later, and Elizabeth looks fine. Though she doesn't look as good in game as in the game thumbnails on steam.

Other than that, game is very pretty. 41GB storage required for a reason I guess.

Overall: I recommend this game, BUT you shouldn't expect Bioshock out of it. It's so different it might as well be another genre in another franchise. The base game is entirely unconnected to the world of Bioshock. Might explain why I like this while not liking Bioshock (yeah, sue me)

The Burial at Seas DLCs are IMHO an abomination. The game was better off accepting that it was not Bioshock, and I think it was a mistake to try to link Rapture to Columbia.
